												PROS- Tower defence with fully 3D environments, creeps and weapon behaviors- Turrets are varied and use ballistics, as well as AI aiming, instead of automatic guaranteed damage outputs- Player can control fully fleshed out turrets or vehicles to take part in the defence, not just a gimmick- GI Joe/Cold War 1980s trimmings, with historical weapons and creeps and a good amount of tongue-in-cheek- Visuals and sound are excellent (for a game from 2011) Players can also joyfully destroy most level features, leaving levels looking war torn. CONS- World War 1 content, whilst expanded, is inferior to the original Toy Soldiers game. Game breaking bugs etc- Multiplayer issues - DO NOT EXPECT ONLINE MULTIPLAYER TO WORK, split screen is great fun- Will not appeal to those fond of tower defence games full of numbers and fixed variables, or players who don't find the "random and whacky" nature of AI aiming and projectile physics to be enjoyable. If you're a tower defense fan but tired of strict grid-and-number affairs, give Toy Soldiers a try. If you've got any interest in 20th century military history, give Toy Soldiers a try.Instead of coldly precise towers on a grid issuing 10 points of damage every 2.5 seconds to the nearest creep, Toy Soldiers has machine guns snaking lead around the heads of Russian troops, or surface-to-air missiles casting smoky trails as they home in on supersonic US Tomcat jets. A proper realtime game with physics and 3D projectiles instead of simply disguised dice rolls hitting HP sponges.As opposed to weighing up number based tower upgrades, area-of-effects and watching hundreds of creeps marching in a static laneway Toy Soldiers brings real time chaos and player controlled action to the mix. Build your turrets and watch their various attacks interact with the environment and enemy waves without the spreadsheet-precision of regular TD games. Take control of turrets yourself and chain up combos to unleash powerful player controlled call-ins, or hop into a vacant helicopter or tank to sweep the battlefield clean of enemies yourself.Oozing with charm and  great "modelling diorama" asthetics Toy Soldiers is a breakout from the tower defense mould. Containing both the grim madness of the WW1 Western Front as well as the over-the-top 1980s Cold War, Toy Soldiers is a delightful mix of historical homage and video game fun. Contains the best representation of WW1 in a game I've seen, though perhaps the original, un-tweaked Toy Soldiers game nails it better. Only time will tell if TS:C improves or degrades the WW1 content.[UPDATE - Sadly it seems that the World War 1 content is doomed to be buggy and generally inferior to the original, but such is the effect of porting an older game into a newer game engine. Still, the very well polished Cold War aspect of the game is extremely worth the purchase.]

								Toy Soldiers, a very addictive Tower Defense Game that offers Endless hours of fun.Toy Soldiers was Originally released for Xbox Live Arcade back in 2009, The game was mainly about Defending your "Toybox" from the upcoming waves of Soldiers, Vehicles, and Aircraft. The Game took place during World War I, Which had Great old classic music, as well as the old weapons and vehicles from that time. Every Turret has 3 Upgrades, which Obviously the First Upgrade is decent but not too good, the Second Upgrade is better and somewhat Powerful, and the Third Upgrade is the best and most powerful. If you got alot of Points, you would Earn Barrages, but I only think there was only one on the Original Toy Soldiers, which would Bomb pretty much the whole Map. You could also Place some Barb wire so its a bit difficult for enemies on foot to reach your Toybox. The game was silly, but at the same time, It wasnt too silly, Which was absolutley Perfect. You could Fly Airplanes, Drive Tanks, You could be a Sniper and snipe all of the Soldiers, you could Control the Turrets, and You could even control the Missles that you launched from Some Turrets. The game was obviously a great success, So they made another Toy Soldiers, Toy Soldiers: Cold War. This Game was absolutley great as well, the Game was more Modern, It had more Modern Vehicles and Weapons. The Game had More Barrages, and Lots of more hecticness. But one thing that was very great about this Game, is that you can actually take part on the battle on Foot, as a Commando. The Commando can be very Destructive and very useful, and there isnt anything better than Hearing the Commando do his Insane screams as you Blow up everything in your path. The Game still had what the game was meant for, Its somewhat silly but serious gamestyle.The Game also featured Survival and Minigames which is Very Interesting. You could also do Versus with a friend (Same for the Original Toy Soldiers), and you could finally Play the Campaign with your friend, which offers just lots of Fun.Then, Signal Studios had one of the best Idea's, To port the original Toy Soldiers and Toy Soldiers: Cold War onto PC into one game: Toy Soldiers: Complete. Although its in Early Acess, They are Fixing it pretty much every month and are making sure this Port isnt one of those Crappy ports you find from the Consoles. You get Both of the Toy Soldier's, Plus you get all of the DLC from their Games, Plus you get Steam Cards, and New Exclusive Content that were never on the Xbox Live Arcade's Toy Soldiers. All of that for only $9.99, Which is a VERY good deal. Both of the Toy Soldier's used to be $14.99 each, and that wasnt even Including their DLC. Although there are Quite some bugs in this game, It is Very well worth $9.99, Do not have Second thoughts about getting this Game, it is Fun, Addicting, and well worth the hours spent.I rate 10/10, Simply because I believe that Signal Studios did an Absolutley amazing Job on the Toy Soldier's Games, and with both of them Combined into one game, Just makes it even more Amazing.

								The first Toy Soldiers is one of my all time favorite games. The fact that this has the original Toy Soldiers and all of its DLC AND the second Toy Soldier and all of ITS DLC for $10 is amazing. At the time of writing this review I have 1.6 hours clocked in and have barley worked through the first campaign of the Cold War part, this pack gives you a lot of bang for your buck. I grew up playing countless tower defense flash games and this game is by far the best in the tower defense genre I have played. The selling-point mechanic that sets this game apart from other tower defense games is that you can take control of your various towers and vehicles on the map to fight the waves of enemies head on. While controlling a tower the game will give it bonus abilities, for example an AI mortar tower will fire one round then aim and fire again; when the play controls that same tower they can now fire three mortars in quick succession or take control of one fired shell, altering its course slightly and speed dramatically. However you can play the entire game without touching a vehicle or controlling a tower and play it as any other tower defense game, the vehicles and tower control will just give you that extra edge when things get tense and enemies slip through the lines.This game is beautifully themed and designed, all the soldiers, vehicles, towers, and environments are in the style of an old war diorama model kit. The vehicles are all wind up, the soldiers are all display figures, the towers are all little glued together models, and the maps all take place in open model terrain cases, complete with painted cardboard sky and cloud borders on maps that give you a plane. One of my favorite parts of the game is the ability to pause it at any time and enter "Tilt-Shift mode" which brings the depth of field and focal point really close up and drops the camera to near the ground so you can take some awesome screenshots, check out my Toy Soldiers screenshots on my profile for some examples.The maps offer a fair bit of challenge to them but you can always make it harder by playing on a harder difficultly. There are other gamemodes like Survival and with this complete pack there's even multiplayer, but I haven't tried that out yet.A final note is that the music and sound design is superb, Signal has really made a great game, I consider this my 'perfect game' for this genre.

Take a look at my new review for this game:Toy Soldiers Complete....what can I say about it. Well I can say  it's only half of a good game.  Cold War is awesome, it has explosions, easy to learn mechanics, and overall good gameplay (and the DLC is free!).  There are a few issues in Cold War but are not very noticeable. TS1 in this game....sucks.  There are so many problems with TS1 in this game.  I own the original Toy Soldiers, so when I bought TS:C I expected TS1 to be an exact port, but I was wrong.  SO MANY GLITCHES can be found in TS1 in this game, and even after a new update comes out some glitches still remain unfixed (and continuously remain unfixed even after constant updates).  Signal Studios tried to combine what they did in Cold War in their "remastered" version of TS1,  by adding Turbo Charge, Barrages, and other things, but these additions only reduced the quality of the game.  The barrages in the TS:C version of TS1 are just the Cold War barrages but polished to look different, and I'm pretty sure World War I nor Toy Soldiers 1 had an orbital laser, it's just madness!   Signal Studios should've just stuck to their guns, but they just had to add something new.  I get that Signal Studios wanted to balance the games so in VS. mode one team couldn't have a higher advantage over the other, but what they did here was just terrible. Here is a list of 10 glitches and inaccuracies in this version of TS1 included in this game: 1) Whenever the Chemical Level 3 is used, it leaves behind the gas cloud and it loops over and over. 2) Whenever the Machine Gun Level 3 is used, the muzzle can be quite blinding. 3) Some enemy units are overpowered and have way too much health. 4) The Anti-Air guns have this annoying gravity bullet velocity that forces you to shoot higher and due to this renders the Anti-Air gun's AI to be completely useless. 5) The Anti-Tank guns are just the models of the Level 3 Anti-Infantry guns taken from the original TS1. 6) TS1 bosses have a bit too little health. 7) The Machine Gun models are also taken from TS1, which is ok, but the models are from the wrong parts of the game. 8) The Sniper Tower is really just a Machine Gun Level 2 but modified.9) The Mortars have the same effects from Cold War. 10) The sounds for the Chemicals Levels 1 and 2 are swapped. There's plenty more glitches and inaccuracies in this version of TS1.  If you want Cold War on PC,  go ahead, buy this acursed thing. If you don't have TS1 and instead buy this game thinking it has the original TS1, you'll be very disappointed.  The only thing that's worth buying in this game is Cold War, but that's about it. This game is only half good and half completed. Cold War is ok; but TS1 in this game sucks. If I were you, I wouldn't buy it. Instead I'd wait for Toy Soldiers: War Chest to come out and then buy the original, 100% authentic, no doubt about it, not sheet TS1 on PC. The original TS1 does have Windows Live Arcade and it forces you to play online, but just deal with it, be glad it has SteamWorks at least. Thank goodness Ubisoft is making the next Toy Soldiers, because I think they will do a whole lot better job than Signal Studios ever did with this damn game.  I know this game is still in Early Access, but this is just lousy.4.8/10

For example: level 2 anti-tank turrets lose their shell cams, which is useful for targeting long distance enemies. The rest is simple: defend your toy box (base) from enemies. There's a campaign mode and two mini campaigns (previously DLC) along with versus, survival and minigames. The game also supports coop, but I haven't tried it on PC yet. Toy Soldiers has plenty to offer at the moment, as it's well polished, funny and most of all: fun. In it's current state it's well worth $10, but once it make it out of early access (and includes the original Toy Soldiers) it'll be a steal.

												Toy soldiers is an enjoyable merger of tower defense strategy and arcade action. Not a deep game, but good light entertainment. As a kid, I loved to play with plastic toy soldiers and this game may be thought of as seeing those childhood games come to life, including the embellishments of a child's imagination. In contrast to some other reviewers, I found the Cold War missions to be generally bug free and stable. There is the very occasional crash to desktop, but otherwise Toy Soldiers functions well. For those of you who have played the original Toy Soldiers, the Great War missions in this version are similar, but not exactly the same. The ability to earn barrages (one-shot area effect attacks) is a nice addition, but I think that the balance is off on some of the missions compared to the original. One difficulty that affects both the Great War and Cold War parts of the game is that control of fixed-aircraft almost requires a gamepad or joystick. The original Toy Soldiers worked just fine with keyboard and mouse, but this version does not use keyboard input, making planes almost unplayable with a mouse only. I found it possible to complete the missions without using the jets or biplanes. Helicopters work just fine.

Posted: August 15, 2016
												This is one of my favorite game series out there. After finding the origional Toy solider back on the Xbox marketplace, I was immediately taken in by the perfect balance between tower defense, RTS, and a bit of some 3rd person shooting elements. The WWI theme was well executed and the "fiction" aspects, such as the rare tanks and bosses, only further developed the theme.The series continues by extending into the Cold War. Just like before, the mixture of gameplay styles blend well together and the theme is noticeable. However, despite the "raw fun" gameplay; there are some issues. The user interface isn't as intuitive as before; as switching/selecting units can be difficult at times, due to some wonky hit boxes and camera angles. There are also their far share of bugs, ranging from hilarious to game breaking. On one hand, the game froze but was quick to recover to a good auto-save system; on the other hand, two bosses fell threw the stage and were killed near immediately. This left me more disappointed than anything else, as I really do enjoy the creative boss fights.Overall, the polish isn't there but it is clear that the dev team made an effort to create a fun/unique experience that builds of the previous game.

Early Access Review
								What an awful game, it has potential to be very good, but there are a lot of buggy concepts that badly let it down. In the first game WWI, on the level 10 of the 3rd mission, the final 2 wheeled large gun carriage thingumy simply sinks into the map never to be seen again, preventing completion of the map. No amount of reloading or replaying the map will stop it from sinking into the map. This particular defect has been outstanding for at least a couple of months.The AI is fairly useless, for example in Cold War series, on the map where you have helicopters flying in, the biggest suite of defects is that the Tank Destroyer AI turrets will not fire at anything that is not on your side of the map, refusing to fire at anything on the Soviet side of the map, unless you are personally controlling them. What makes it a real challenge is the fact that you are revealed to have two HQs, one on the Soviet side of the map (what should be the Soviet toybox is actually your 2nd toybox), that you can't properly defend (because surprise surprise you can't put turrets on the Soviet side to defend it). So one set of enemy tanks start on the Soviet side and then stream into your Soviet-side HQ and the rest of the vehicles/ tanks stream into the actual US HQ (toy box) on your side of the map. So because you have 2 HQs, you lose the scenario even faster. Oh yes and the 2nd Soviet Anti-Aircraft battery that you are meant to destroy is also missing. In this particular scenario, when left to the AI, not enough cash is racked up to aid with selling battery emplacements to allow you to buy anti-aircraft (armoured Soviet helicopters) batteries (and you need at least 4, or 2 upgraded with you controlling one) to defeat the helicopters. Of course then you have virtually no funds left to sell the anti-aircraft batteries and replace them with machine-gun batteries to defend vs the final level.The other major defect is not being able to freely scroll over the map, you are forced to select an battery emplacement and use it to bug out and select another battery to move over the battlefield. Trying to scroll or move the view to see another battery and the game simply prevents you from doing anything. You are stuck in a corner or a useless part of the map, unable to scroll or move your focus. This game is far from Complete, more like Alpha test with a LOT of outstanding basic game handling concepts yet to be resolved.

												This is a great game if you wish to play single player or local split screen multiplayer but please avoid if your sole intention is to play it online! I have tried playing this game over many connections and all say they are catching up with a slow network connection.MORE INFORMATION REGARDING ONLINE MULTIPLAYEROnce loaded you will have a game that is playing around a quarter of real time. This will happen regardless of your internet connection speed, tests have shown that there is more than enough network bandwidth on the network and connection yet the game still insists that the network is slow and reduces its speed to a crawl!
